pullRequest.title: UI Notebook Asset Search
pullRequest.bodyText: Notebook to showcase how to use the UI to search for assets. I originally wanted to include lineage demo as well, but there are still some issues with kafka messages going missing. Therefore, I have broken up this into potentially two parts: One lab with using the UI for searching and the other with data lineage.

commit.message:
add open-lineage server name to UI docker configuration

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

add lib path to datalake compose configuration for open-lineage

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

add auxiliary files for the UI lab

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

notebook to demo asset search in the UI

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:odpi/egeria into ui-notebook

nodes.bodyText:
We now set this when building the docker container via ENV LOADER_PATH=/opt/egeria/server/lib in the egeria dockerfile. That value is needed to dynamically pick up connectors.
Did you need anything else?
the current value will break other notebooks such as discovery as we won't be able to load the connectors - this value here overrides the others.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -74,6 +74,8 @@ services:
         depends_on:
             - kafka
         image: '${egeria_repo}/egeria:${egeria_version}'
+        environment:
+            - LOADER_PATH=/opt/egeria/lib

nodes.bodyText:
If this fits in best with the scenario we can use it technically.
However cocoMDS1 is for 'data lake operations', whilst cocoMDS4 is for 'data lake users. It seems the latter ie original value is preferable.
If there are additional OMASs needed for cocoMDS4 then I think we should look at changing the configuration there rather than pointing the UI to the inappropriate server?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -104,7 +106,10 @@ services:
         command: /bin/bash -c "java -jar /opt/egeria/user-interface/ui-chassis-spring-${egeria_version}.jar"
         environment:
             - OMAS_SERVER_URL=http://datalake:8080
-            - OMAS_SERVER_NAME=cocoMDS4
+            - OMAS_SERVER_NAME=cocoMDS1

nodes.bodyText:
It's important we keep the k8s/compose configurations consistent -- indeed there's a fair chance we may at some point deprecate compose -- it's far more limited.
So These variables will also need adding to open-metadata-resources/open-metadata-deployment/charts/odpi-egeria-lab/templates/egeria-ui.yaml . Follow the pattern used for "OMAS_SERVER_URL"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -104,7 +106,10 @@ services:
         command: /bin/bash -c "java -jar /opt/egeria/user-interface/ui-chassis-spring-${egeria_version}.jar"
         environment:
             - OMAS_SERVER_URL=http://datalake:8080
-            - OMAS_SERVER_NAME=cocoMDS4
+            - OMAS_SERVER_NAME=cocoMDS1
+            - OPEN_LINEAGE_SERVER_URL=http://datalake:8080

nodes.bodyText: See comment on cocoMDS above
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -0,0 +1,290 @@ +{ + "cells": [ + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "![Egeria Logo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/odpi/egeria/master/assets/img/ODPi_Egeria_Logo_color.png)\n", + "\n", + "### ODPi Egeria Hands-On Lab\n", + "# Welcome to the UI Asset Search Lab" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## Introduction\n", + "\n", + "ODPi Egeria is an open source project that provides open standards and implementation libraries to connect tools, catalogs and platforms together so they can share information (called metadata) about data and the technology that supports it.\n", + "\n", + "In this hands-on lab you will get a chance to have hands-on experience with the UI of Egeria, by searching for assets we add along the way." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## The Scenario\n", + "\n", + "The ODPi Egeria team use the personas and scenarios from the fictitious company called Coco Pharmaceuticals. (See https://opengovernance.odpi.org/coco-pharmaceuticals/ for more information).\n", + "\n", + "As part of the huge business transformation that Coco Pharmaceuticals has embarked on, they\n", + "have created a data lake for managing data for research, analytics, exchange between their internal organizations and business partners (such as hospitals). As a result, the data lake has to be\n", + "designed to handle a wide variety of data, including some highly sensitive and regulated data.\n", + "\n", + "In this lab we use first data engine to import pre-defined assets. Afterwards, the UI where we can search for assets is shown. The main character engaged in this lab is the data scientist named Callie Quartile." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "> **Callie Quartile:** Data Scientist" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## Setting up\n", + "\n", + "Coco Pharmaceuticals make widespread use of ODPi Egeria for tracking and managing their data and related assets.\n", + "Figure 1 below shows their metadata servers and the Open Metadata and Governance (OMAG) Server Platforms that are hosting them. Each metadata server supports a department in the organization. The servers are distributed across the platform to even out the workload. Servers can be moved to a different platform if needed.\n", + "\n", + "![Figure 1](../images/coco-pharmaceuticals-systems-omag-server-platforms.png)\n", + "> **Figure 1:** Coco Pharmaceuticals' OMAG Server Platforms\n", + "\n", + "The code below sets up the network addresses for the three platforms. This varies depending on whether you are running them locally, through **docker-compose** or on **kubernetes**." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "code", + "execution_count": null, + "metadata": {}, + "outputs": [], + "source": [ + "%run ../common/environment-check.ipynb" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "----\n", + "Callie is using the data lake operations metadata server called `cocoMDS1`. This server is hosted on the Data Lake OMAG Server Platform.\n",

nodes.bodyText:
I'm somewhat uncomfortable with using 'precanned' events to demonstrate the capability.
We should either be

importing from an archive
OR
using the API to create/link things

(couldn't comment on file as very big)
Also 'IGC' is proprietary, and this should be primarily referring to open technology.

Then re-run the previous step to ensure all of the servers are started." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "----\n", + "## Exercise 1\n", + "\n", + "### Importing IGC events\n", + "\n", + "IBM InfoSphere Information Governance Catalog (IGC) is a tool that allows you to create, manage and share a common business language, document and enact policies and rules and track data lineage.\n", + "\n", + "For this part of the exercises, we have prepared a set of events for Data Engine OMAS in `cocoMDS1` to pick up. The precise process on how these events have been created is more comvoluted, and is out of scope of this lab." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "#### Install kafka-python" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "We will send the IGC events through the kafka bus. The `kafka-python` package allows us to interact with kafka directly with Python."

nodes.bodyText:
If we need extra packages for our notebooks it's probably best to add to open-metadata-resources/open-metadata-deployment/docker/jupyter/requirements.txt which has recently been added. This adds reliability/improves speed/reduces complexity as the relevant package will 'be there'
THEN in addition we need to add to the instructions for people running locally... and so I can see you might want to leave it here anyway... perhaps do both to cater for all cases. a little undecided on this one

nodes.bodyText: I'm uncomfortable with only referring to IGC as the example. We need a generic version ... and I think it's then ok to also add IGC specific, but IGC only sends the wrong message IMO about being open - at least if this is in the 'core' project (as opposed to other sandpit/3rd party repos?)

nodes.bodyText:
Not necessarily. It will be be

https://localhost:8443 locally
https://datalake:8443 OR https://localhost:18443 in compose
https://<one-of-my-k8s-nodes>:30443 in k8s

We may need to ensure we inject the right environment variables into the jupyter container so that it can display the correct value (if we can't determine it within the notebook)

It is used in all of the server configuration documents to connect it to Kafka." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "code", + "execution_count": null, + "metadata": {}, + "outputs": [], + "source": [ + "import os\n", + "\n", + "eventBusURLroot = os.environ.get('eventBusURLroot', 'localhost:9092')" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "The IGC events to create assets are located in the text file `igc-events.txt`. One line represents one event. The kafka topic we should send these events to is `egeria.omag.openmetadata.repositoryservices.cohort.cocoCohort.OMRSTopic`." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "code", + "execution_count": null, + "metadata": {}, + "outputs": [], + "source": [ + "from kafka import KafkaProducer, KafkaClient\n", + "\n", + "producer = KafkaProducer(bootstrap_servers=eventBusURLroot)\n", + "\n", + "with open('igc-events.txt', 'r') as f:\n", + " for line in f:\n", + " producer.send(\n", + " 'egeria.omag.openmetadata.repositoryservices.cohort.cocoCohort.OMRSTopic', \n", + " str.encode(line)\n", + " )" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "The code above reads one event at a time, and sends it to the `egeria.omag.openmetadata.repositoryservices.cohort.cocoCohort.OMRSTopic` kafka topic. All OMAS servers listening to this topic will attempt to pick up and process these events. Once successful, we can search for the assets in the UI." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## Exercise 2\n", + "\n", + "### Search for assets in the UI" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "Now we can go to the UI, located at:\n", + "```\n", + "https://localhost:18443\n",

commit.message:
Use cocoMDS4 instead of 1 for the notebook usecase, also remove the dependency to the janus connector jar

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:odpi/egeria into ui-notebook

add data-engine to cocoMDS4

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

change cocoMDS1 to cocoMDS4 in the notebook

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

Add also UI config to k8s config

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

add environment variable for Egeria UI for the notebook

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

Add kafka-python to requirements.txt for notebook

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

Add introduction and short description to the UI labs

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

Remove igc_events.txt from the lab repository as it already exists in another location

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:odpi/egeria into ui-notebook

create simple assets with asset owner OMAS instead of using kafka

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

remove kafka-python from requirements for the notebook

Signed-off-by: Nguyen Tran <ntran.egeria.git@nitromailbox.com>

nodes.bodyText: In this lab we first - 'use' is superfluous
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,268 @@
+{
+ "cells": [
+  {
+   "cell_type": "markdown",
+   "metadata": {},
+   "source": [
+    "![Egeria Logo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/odpi/egeria/master/assets/img/ODPi_Egeria_Logo_color.png)\n",
+    "\n",
+    "### ODPi Egeria Hands-On Lab\n",
+    "# Welcome to the UI Asset Search Lab"
+   ]
+  },
+  {
+   "cell_type": "markdown",
+   "metadata": {},
+   "source": [
+    "## Introduction\n",
+    "\n",
+    "ODPi Egeria is an open source project that provides open standards and implementation libraries to connect tools, catalogs and platforms together so they can share information (called metadata) about data and the technology that supports it.\n",
+    "\n",
+    "In this hands-on lab you will get a chance to have hands-on experience with the UI of Egeria, by searching for assets we add along the way."
+   ]
+  },
+  {
+   "cell_type": "markdown",
+   "metadata": {},
+   "source": [
+    "## The Scenario\n",
+    "\n",
+    "The ODPi Egeria team use the personas and scenarios from the fictitious company called Coco Pharmaceuticals.  (See https://opengovernance.odpi.org/coco-pharmaceuticals/ for more information).\n",
+    "\n",
+    "As part of the huge business transformation that Coco Pharmaceuticals has embarked on, they\n",
+    "have created a data lake for managing data for research, analytics, exchange between their internal organizations and business partners (such as hospitals).  As a result, the data lake has to be\n",
+    "designed to handle a wide variety of data, including some highly sensitive and regulated data.\n",
+    "\n",
+    "In this lab we use first create some assets. Afterwards, the UI where we can search for assets is shown. The main character engaged in this lab is the data scientist named [Callie Quartile](https://github.com/odpi/data-governance/blob/master/docs/coco-pharmaceuticals/personas/callie-quartile.md)."

nodes.bodyText: In the 'building a data catalog' notebook, Peter Profile is the creator of data sets, whilst callie is using them for her research. So maybe we need 2 personas involved here.

nodes.bodyText:
Unfortunately a directory link doesn't work in jupyter, we just get
File Load Error for asset-management-labs
asset-management-labs is a directory, not a file

So you may want to just link to one of the files, or alternatively add another README.ipynb in that directory if needed - probably the first option is simpler
nodes.diffHunk: @@ -0,0 +1,268 @@ +{ + "cells": [ + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "![Egeria Logo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/odpi/egeria/master/assets/img/ODPi_Egeria_Logo_color.png)\n", + "\n", + "### ODPi Egeria Hands-On Lab\n", + "# Welcome to the UI Asset Search Lab" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## Introduction\n", + "\n", + "ODPi Egeria is an open source project that provides open standards and implementation libraries to connect tools, catalogs and platforms together so they can share information (called metadata) about data and the technology that supports it.\n", + "\n", + "In this hands-on lab you will get a chance to have hands-on experience with the UI of Egeria, by searching for assets we add along the way." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## The Scenario\n", + "\n", + "The ODPi Egeria team use the personas and scenarios from the fictitious company called Coco Pharmaceuticals. (See https://opengovernance.odpi.org/coco-pharmaceuticals/ for more information).\n", + "\n", + "As part of the huge business transformation that Coco Pharmaceuticals has embarked on, they\n", + "have created a data lake for managing data for research, analytics, exchange between their internal organizations and business partners (such as hospitals). As a result, the data lake has to be\n", + "designed to handle a wide variety of data, including some highly sensitive and regulated data.\n", + "\n", + "In this lab we use first create some assets. Afterwards, the UI where we can search for assets is shown. The main character engaged in this lab is the data scientist named [Callie Quartile](https://github.com/odpi/data-governance/blob/master/docs/coco-pharmaceuticals/personas/callie-quartile.md)." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "> **Callie Quartile:** Data Scientist" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## Setting up\n", + "\n", + "Coco Pharmaceuticals make widespread use of ODPi Egeria for tracking and managing their data and related assets.\n", + "Figure 1 below shows their metadata servers and the Open Metadata and Governance (OMAG) Server Platforms that are hosting them. Each metadata server supports a department in the organization. The servers are distributed across the platform to even out the workload. Servers can be moved to a different platform if needed.\n", + "\n", + "![Figure 1](../images/coco-pharmaceuticals-systems-omag-server-platforms.png)\n", + "> **Figure 1:** Coco Pharmaceuticals' OMAG Server Platforms\n", + "\n", + "The code below sets up the network addresses for the three platforms. This varies depending on whether you are running them locally, through **docker-compose** or on **kubernetes**." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "code", + "execution_count": null, + "metadata": {}, + "outputs": [], + "source": [ + "%run ../common/environment-check.ipynb" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "----\n", + "Callie is using the data lake metadata server called `cocoMDS4`. This server is hosted on the Data Lake OMAG Server Platform. It enables business users and the executive team to access data from the data lake.\n", + "\n", + "Check that `cocoMDS4` is running. \n", + "\n", + "If any of the platforms are not running, follow [this link to set up and run the platform](https://egeria.odpi.org/open-metadata-resources/open-metadata-labs/). If any server is reporting that it is not configured then\n", + "run the steps in the **[Server Configuration](../egeria-server-config.ipynb)** lab to configure\n", + "the servers. Then re-run the previous step to ensure all of the servers are started." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "----\n", + "## Exercise 1\n", + "\n", + "### Generating some assets\n", + "\n", + "Before we can interact with the UI, we have to create some data in the metadata repository. This section is a simplified version of the [Asset Management Labs](../asset-management-labs/). If you haven't done so already, it is recommended that you also check those labs out.\n",

nodes.bodyText: Ah so Peter is involved - good. Let's add his picture further app along with Callie.We could also say 'Peter is going to create some CSV files'? We tend to write what the personas do in our other notebooks so I think it's best to adopt the same style (even though the text is technically correct)

nodes.bodyText:
In the k8s environment the URL will be quite different. I'm not 100% sure how to figure out as it's highly dependent on the external IP address. probably can figure out.
May be best we put in as is, and then raise an issue to correct the ports for k8s - which I can do for you.

+              value: "https://localhost:18443"

For a more thorough explanation for this step, check out the [Building a Data Catalog lab](../asset-management-labs/building-a-data-catalog.ipynb)." + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "code", + "execution_count": null, + "metadata": {}, + "outputs": [], + "source": [ + "for csv_file_specs in csv_file_list:\n", + " response_guid = assetOwnerCreateCSVAsset(\n", + " serverName=cocoMDS1Name, \n", + " serverPlatformName=cocoMDS1PlatformName, \n", + " serverPlatformURL=cocoMDS1PlatformURL, \n", + " userId=petersUserId,\n", + " **csv_file_specs\n", + " )\n", + " printGUIDList(response_guid)" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "## Exercise 2\n", + "\n", + "### Search for assets in the UI" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "markdown", + "metadata": {}, + "source": [ + "Now we can get the URL through the environment variable, with a default value of `https://localhost:18443`:" + ] + }, + { + "cell_type": "code", + "execution_count": null, + "metadata": {}, + "outputs": [], + "source": [ + "uiURL = os.environ.get('uiExternalURL', 'https://localhost:18443')\n",

nodes.bodyText:
We haven't used this in the tutorial yet. Not in itself a big issue.
But I do think this is the wrong server -- cocoMDS4 is for users, not for operational engines to use. That should be cocoMDS1 I think
